p: A large proportion of the globe has experienced climate change since the 20th century. Using the global mean surface air temperature, it has been determined that the reported increases in mean daily temperatures are due, at least partially, to differential changes in the maximum and minimum temperatures [ 1]. On most continents, the diurnal temperature range, defined as the difference between daily maximum and minimum temperatures, proved to be decreasing, this is due to the obvious increase in night temperatures, and less distinct or absent increases in day temperatures [ 1]. Numerous changes in climatic and environmental conditions as well as local land use can affect DTR (diurnal range of air temperature) [ 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]. In addition, there is a growing consensus that the asymmetrical diurnal warming of air affects various ecological processes [ 7, 8, 9, 10, 11]. In China, DTR has significantly decreased on both regional and national scales over the past several decades. On a regional basis, the magnitude of the decrease was greater in northern China and smaller in southern China [ 5, 6, 12, 13, 14].
